This is a bit of a hidden place and was a bit hard to find.  It is quite small with about a dozen tables inside and about another 6 outside.  It seemed to be packed and busy the entire time we were there.  It took us awhile to get service from our waitress who completely apologized because they were slammed.  Every waitress was running around as fast as they could.  Coffee was decent and the food was good but nothing totally amazing.  It did come out quite quickly and was tasty.  Good place for busy downtown Chicago.

Unique location in the last skyscraper before the big bust. Chicago has one cool skyline, it really does. Recommend you look on a map if you haven't been here before.  Visited on a Friday for brunch, when we arrived it was pretty quiet but the breakfast guests must have finished and lunch was about to start I guess. A diner feel to the place, food was very average and quantity v quality applies here. Neither of us finished our meals, mine was the corned beef hash. Food was brought out within minutes, making me assume a frozen v fresh approach to food here. Bill was reasonable, but I really wouldn't have paid anymore. Bloody Mary's were different, don't think I've had meat on a drink before. But they were pretty tasty. Really would verge on 2.5 stars, but we'll give them the benefit of doubt. Please be wary of anyone that gives this place more then three stars.

Is a nice place, well kept in an old and pretty building, made it 11:02 am and was able to still get special breakfast price... Coffee was good and my eggs overeasy, crispy bacon has browns and toast came pretty fast(3mins) sevice was really good( Delfina)

Um no, just no. I sat down to a clean and set table and noticed that the silverware had been used. Gross. The hash browns looked like they were dumped out of an Ore Ida bag. Not that those are necessarily bad, but I can make that sh*t at home. I want real potatoes, with real veggies and real herbs and spices. I couldn't even cut through the turkey sausage patties and finally gave up. I'm a bit of a rebel, so I was determined to win against the patty, but alas, I wasn't strong enough. Sigh. The toast looked like it was made from those 99 cent bags of bread that may or may not have been stepped on.  The only thing remotely interesting or impressive about this place was the "indoor patio" located in a beautiful old Chicago building with some interesting history. I've got nothing against a greasy spoon and in fact that was my mission on this particular morning, but damn yo', you gotta wash that spoon occasionally. Next.

For all you AMEX black card holders you can't use them here! Cash, Visa or Mastercard. Thanks, Yelp, for helping me find this. There's signage on the street but it's one of those places that apparently sits inside in a big office building. You simply just can't peek through a window and see everyone having a jolly good time over lunch. I walked in, took a seat at the bar (a diner-like bar, not to be confused where one would order a beer) and placed an order for the Pittsfield burger, a Chicago-style dog and an omelette for the lady. My recommendation is to eat there. It has a cool, very home-like, yet travel-diner feel. I took the food to go and by the time I was back at my hotel my fries were soggy and the bread was a little soft. The burger patty appeared to be one of those frozen packaged ones. It was still pretty good. I was craving a Chicago-style hot dog and really enjoyed their version with the exception of relish. Serving sizes were great or was it just weird that I ordered two meals for myself? ;)

Discovered this place thanks to Yelp while in town for a wedding. DELICIOUS!! Very good service, and fast--within 5 minutes of ordering we had our food! I had a skillet with corned beef hash & my boyfriend had the chef skillet. Bloody Mary and Mimosa were also really great. Coffee as well. Also very reasonably priced for a downtown restaurant--didn't break my budget at all. So happy to have found this, and I'll definitely remember it when I'm back again!!

I really like this place!  I went here breakfast and it was really good.  They make their own corn beef Hash.  Their specialty are their skillets. I had a skillet with corn beef hash, hashbrowns, and three eggs over easy. It was OMG good! This is good old-fashioned American breakfast in a beautiful old building with amazing architecture. Next time you're in Chicago, forget Denny's and go here!

Everything about my experience was terrible. However I'm giving it a 2 stars cause I may have failed to order and because the location is just too cute.  I ordered eggs and French toast, I was super hungry. The eggs are extremely salty, the French toast were fine. The Turkey sausages seemed like any frozen ones you would buy on wallmart. How come it's called a cafe when you can't even get a latte ?? Are you kidding me? The waiters are very rude, they gave my food in a plastic box when I wanted to dine in, when I asked her why she explained in a bored fed up tone and I didn't even understand why can't I get my food in a real plate like everyone else!!  The people who cook don't wear gloves, I saw them with my own eyes touching the bread without any gloves before serving it. I feel I could have ordered something much better than what I did, but the rudeness and mess is unforgivable ..

Pittsfield Cafe is a very standard and affordable diner located in one of the most vintage buildings of downtown Chicago. The cafe is very old school with seating in the atrium, deemed "one of the loveliest ever designed by the firm" by architectural historian Sally Chappell. The atrium is five stories high and embellished with marble and brass. It's perfect for breakfast and lunch for locals as well as visitors from out-of-town.  The menu is classic with breakfast served throughout the day. It's an optimal choice for breakfast if you prefer a relaxed and quiet atmosphere. Lunch, on the other hand, is usually bustling with the work crowd. I had the "chef's recommend" which is basically two cooked eggs, two sausage links, hash brown, and toast. It was very basic and filling for just $8 with tip and tax.
What kind of restaurant that serves breakfast all day won't make you a poached egg after 11? That's absurd.
Love this place!!! The food is great and so affordable for downtown!  The wait staff is super friendly and you can tell some of the customers have been going there for years!  I'll be back!

I have been here several times, and the food is always great, especially their breakfast.    We got there ahead of a big rush, and ate, "Outside".  It took forever to get service, thus no 5 stars.  Once a waitress, not ours, took our orders, our food was up in minutes, like 2 or 3.  They do need better staff, but the food is do good, an at such a great price, we both decided it could have been a LOT worse.  The guy who was supposed to wait on us did apologize before we left as well.  NOW that is cool.   If you are in the loop, check this place out.  It might have an unusual outside eating area, but it is worth it

This place has the best Tuna Melt in Chicago. the staff is always so friendly and it's a hidden gem in Chicago. No tourist in sight and when you eat here, you can feel the history of when this place was opened.

When I walked in I thought to myself, I wish I would have brought my ex girlfriend here... But that warm fuzzy feeling I got soon left. The server was kinda rude. She looked at me like I was stupid when I was surprised that they have a $7 order of corned beef hash that comes with nothing but the corned beef hash. I've seriously never heard or just eating a heaping plate of corned beef hash by its self. I have always ordered it as part of a traditional diner breakfast, eggs, hash and toast... I decided on broccoli and cheddar omelet and I asked for one pancake on the side. She said she's couldn't get me one pancake but that a short stack of four pancakes was $4.99. Then when she brought them there was only two cakes. I asked her to clarify and again with the dumb look. $4.99 for 2 pancakes seems a little overpriced, besides the misinformation. Either way, the food was alright(pretty average diner breakfast) but the server was impersonal and rude and only came back to drop off the check. I probably won't eat here again based on service and price but the atmosphere and look is cool for sure, very prohibition era-esq. Be sure to check out the bathroom, lol. For the price I'd go to Wildberry or Eggy's just a little bit further east on Randolph, but I guess this place is worth a go just for the experience of seeing it.

Had the Rib Eye Steak and eggs. Cooked perfect medium rare. Steak was a bit gristle... but what do you want for a $10 breakfast. Food came out super fast and staff was extremely attentive to keeping my iced tea full. Small traditional cafe inside of a building lobby at street level. Would eat here again for sure. Only complaint was no sourdough bread for my toast.
The location is a bit hidden and there's not a window to be found, but the food is great and the service friendly.  I will definitely be back to this little hidden gem of a diner.

When looking for a classic diner spot in a vintage building, look no further than the Pittsfield Café. It might be a little tricky to find, but it is worth it. I think I always get the Reuben, but it is perfectly done. Service is fast and pleasant. The food is inexpensive and the portions are huge.  I love the Pittsfield so much that I have had two of my birthday lunches with co-workers here. On my most recent birthday, the waitstaff surprised me with a slice of cheesecake and a song!

We came here after we saw that the wait at Wildberry was 1 hour. We had the breakfast Santa Fe skillet and pancakes with bananas and nuts. Both were amazing and the service is exceptional. There was no wait mid afternoon on a Saturday, and there is seating in the Pittsfield atrium outside the cafe which offers gorgeous architecture views. It was a perfect place for a brunch date on the weekend!

You never really need a reason or excuse to wake up late on a Saturday morning and have breakfast/brunch. This was my predicament on my last day in Chicago. A quick Yelp search landed me at Pittsfield Cafe which was very close to my hotel. It is located on the main floor of an office building. However, there was a sign outside so it was not hard to miss. The cafe is nicely tucked away inside. It is not very big but they do have seating in the "lobby" area. I was seated promptly inside. Everyone was in green for St. Patrick's Day and very cheerful.  I received/ordered a nice cup of coffee. There were many menu options ranging from omelets to pancakes to skillets. I settled on a meat omelet with hash browns and toast. The meat omelet had sausage, bacon, and cheese. I was so excited about it. My food arrived very quickly and it was cooked perfectly. It tasted just as good as it looked!  The only con would be that it was a little slow to get my check and to pay but not a deal breaker. I wasn't in a rush as I was enjoying my last day in the city.

Our visit at the Pittsfield Cafe was wonderful. Our server, Victoria was knowledgeable and friendly. I will definitely visit here again. The managers work just as hard as the rest of staff. I've worked in the restaurant industry for ten years and admire that. The food was inexpensive and delicious!

Came here for breakfast. I wasn't sure if it was self-seating or if someone seats you; it turned out it was self-seating after I stood there idly for 5 minutes (embarassing). The service was fast afterwards. They're not the most attentive, but they are fast (never got my water glass filled). Food was filling and pretty good for the price. They have breakfast specials that the server pointed out. I order the 2-2-2 (2 eggs, 2 pancakes, 2 sausages). Orange juice tasted fresh. I did enjoy the courtyard feel of it being in the lobby of the Pittsfield Building (beautiful lobby by the way). Good place for a quick breakfast.

Office buildings in the loop often have an old fashioned, American fare diner on the first floor, and the Pittsfield Cafe is my favorite one.  It's a classic set-up - discreetly tucked away from the chaos outside, inside a gothic/art deco building that was once the tallest in Chicago.  Built in 1927, the Pittsfield is named after the Massachusetts town where Marshall Field got his first job.  The food is midwestern comfort, usually far from healthy, and the servers are easygoing enough to make you feel like you're a regular. There are two occasions when I rely on the Pittsfield Cafe: (1) when I have old friends in town during lunch on a weekday and we need somewhere comfortable, calm, and non-touristy to catch up over sandwiches; and (2) when I want a quiet lunch on my own, away from work and with a copy of the newspaper for entertainment.

The place is hidden inside The Pittsfield building, so be on the lookout when entering from Washington. The service was very friendly and the atmosphere was very relaxed. Loved the cafe style tables in the atrium space. Really large portions for the price. The omelets were huge and made with very fresh ingredients.

Came here for brunch our first day in Chicago. Service was great. The food was ok. The utensils... not so great.  He had the Chicken Parmesan which he was satisfied with. I was craving steak and eggs so I had the rib eye steak breakfast. My steak tasted and felt like it was cooked well done plus, if there is such a thing, instead of the medium rare I had asked for. My steak knife couldn't even cut through the meat. I asked for another steak knife and even the second one couldn't really cut through the meat.  Although we weren't really happen with our meal, I'll still give then 3 stars for their customer service. They were very attentive and made sure to always have our cups of coffee and water filled.

I have returned somewhat triumphantly to the Pittsfield Cafe to enjoy the chef's skillet once again.  It did not disappoint.  I was good until dinner due to the smorgasbord of sausage, egg, cheese and hash browns.  I really like this place and it will be one of my go to locations for some time to come.

Cute little diner in the downtown area of the city. Stumbled in here on a cold morning last weekend when my favorite breakfast place up the street was over an hour wait time. It was really quaint inside and I felt like I was in a real diner back in my home town in rural Massachusetts. The bar stools and the window to the kitchen made it extra authentic! The food was just regular breakfast food. I got a strawberry french toast, eggs, hash browns, and sausage while my friend got a skillet. The food was good, large portion size but the best part of all was the low price and our waitress was super nice! It may not be my first choice for breakfast but it will now always be my back up plan! My only complaint was I was lucky I even found the place! Their address does not mach the exact location and they have no signage outside on the building just a small easel low to the ground.
Best pancakes I ever had. Don't know how they make them so light! The place is a little hard to find because you can't see it from the street. It's inside the Pittsfield Bldg.

I came here 6 months ago on a spur of the moment trip to Chicago - and yes I'm still thinking about my Bloody Mary, which is why I'm writing this review.  After reading reviews for other nearby breakfast places we settled on the Pittsfield because a) we were in a rush to get to the Science and Industry Museum and didn't want to get caught up in a crazy brunch rush elsewhere and b) the prices looked great. Thankfully the conceirge at our hotel gave us some pointers on how to get here because its slightly hard to find and Siri was taking us some crazy way. To be honest I don't remember what we ordered... I do remember the plates were huge and we couldn't finish it all...I do remember the service was great... I do remember it was pretty empty considering it was a Saturday morning, and I definitely remember the Bloody Mary was pretty freaking special.  Perhaps the Bloody Mary itself is why I've forgotten most else lol.    We came prepared with cash since other reviews had led us to believe they didn't take credit cards, but I'm pretty sure they were taking credit cards at that time (July 2013) just with a minimum.   If you're looking for a quick, cheap and casual breakfast - think diner style, this is your place.  Sure we all love brunch spots with creme brulee french toast and pulled pork omelettes and whatever else, but the Pittsfield gets the job done if you're not wanting to get so complicated.

Perfect basic diner breakfast. open early, even on the weekend. Coffee is really good. Had the PC Muffin - just one egg and american cheese on a toasted english - classic. And the side of "ham off the bone" was delicious (note, large enough to share unless you're a big eater). Simple, friendly service. Fresh squeezed oj. Solid.

Been stopping here off & on for years for basic greek diner b'fast or lunch. Some of the "foodie" negative reviews - LOL. Double the price & offer $100 bottles of wine - the foodies will LOVE. Cool location - last high rise Chicago before 29 crash. Moorish architecture has not changed much since - cool. Recent rich kid "dormitory" above - no comment.  Remnants of another restaurant long closed below basement - I'd like to see.  rating problems - I can't choose better than "meh". - way to go yelp.

RUDE STAFF!! After being a customer at Pittsfield for the last 5 years, I am sad to say that service is horrible. Buying breakfast and lunch from pittsfield twice a week, you'd think that the staff would be happy to see your face or hear your voice. Not at all!!! The women on the phone who takes orders has no customer service. She does not care about your order, your requests, and gives off so much attitude. The whole staff is the opposite of hospitable. The delivery guy really doesnt care either. Overall, service is bad, but there is a large variety of food which keeps us coming back due to the limited options in the area.
There is nothing about this place that is great. There is one thing that is good and that's the service.  Avoid the tuna stuffed avocado. 2 stars.

Great breakfast spot located in a classy old school building downtown.  I got a vege omelet with potatoes and was full until dinner.  One can dine inside the restaurant or outside in a large atrium of the building.   Phoning in takeout orders can be difficult as the staff's English level isn't perfect.
I had a delicious lunch here this afternoon and it's the best Avacado and three egg meal I've ever had in my life, and I've eaten all over the world for the past 76 years!!
We enjoyed a wonderful breakfast. Perfect Classic eggs cooked over easy, crispy bacon and Greek toast. Not a hash brown fan... always looking for a substitute, more bacon works for me!

This was one of the worst "dining" experiences I've had. We went first to Wildberry a few blocks away but the long wait made us wander over to the Pittsfield Cafe, because of the high star ratings on Yelp. "Pit"tsfield Cafe. This establishment is located inside a building downtown that looks a bit abandoned inside. The "cafe" has seating outside of the store doors and counter and booth seating inside. This place is a dump.  The menu is typical greek/american restaurant style with meat and potatoes and no fruits or veggies. The prices are low for Chicago.  I ordered the pancakes. I asked to add fresh strawberries. Three berries came with the pancakes, and one was pathetically past its prime.  The pancakes were clearly from a powered mix. I was given a little cup of butter. It was dirty, crumbs all over. I told the server and she made an excuse that the kitchen has tight quarters and they have it next to the toaster.  My companion ordered the sampler which was 2 eggs, sausage, and french toast. Worse french toast I have never had. It tasted, I kid you not, like an old leather shoe. One of his eggs was raw - I don't mean the yolk - I mean the white of the egg was still really raw. Not borderline. He said the sausage patties were definitely frozen.  Our server never returned to ask about our food. We couldn't track her down. We asked the busser to locate her. He did not. We never got the check. We went to the cash register to say we wanted to leave, then they wanted our money and found the check. I complained about the horribleness of the food, and they knocked off $4. The total price then was around $18. Not even CLOSE to worth it. The cashier didn't apologize, but instead said that the kitchen got slammed. Well then don't put out so many freakin' tables. No sorry. At this point, two servers are sitting at a booth both on their smart phones. The owner should be absolutely ashamed.  There are a hundred better places in Chicago. For the love of God, go to Cosi or Panera or something. You deserve better.

Breakfast here is legit. be sure to come before 11am to get their special. I got their avocado Benedict, which was served on English muffin and hollandaise sauce, and my friend got the gyros skillet with scrambled eggs and feta cheese. Both were delicious Pic:  yelp.com/user_local_phot… Pic:  yelp.com/user_local_phot…

This was our diamond in the rough while visiting Chicago.  I went with my 2 tween kiddos, as we were trying hard to avoid the 'touristy' aspect of Chicago.  We found it here.  Great traditional style breakfast, great service and great prices.  My son loved sitting at the diner-style counter, but the atrium seating looked really nice too, and had a more quiet ambience. As said, it was difficult to find - hidden in an office building with no street signage - I had to call them.  We were impressed by the beauty of the office building entrance - nice architectural features.  If you are visiting, it's right next to Millenium Park, so was a great start to a day of strolling through the park.

Like all the other reviews have said, it is a bit hidden in the lobby of the Pitsfield Building.  But it was worth the hunt.  A fine traditional Chicago diner.  No tourist that were obvious.  Full menu, friendly service etc.   We went for a late breakfast during the week 9am.  We were seated promptly, well watered and coffied and enjoyed our meal.   NOTE - The yelp address is correct, but the cross streets are wrong.  It is on Washington, south side of street, between Michigan and Wabash.

Pretty decent breakfast place right in downtown Chicago.  Can't beat the prices for this place - I think I paid more in metered parking than I did the food! Slightly on the greasy side, but hey, it's delicious! Make sure you get there at least 30 minutes before closing!  We got there 20 min before, and had to take our orders to go - still really good!

This is my go to place on the eastern end of the Loop. Great food and fast service. The breakfast 222 with 2 pancakes, 2 eggs, and 2 bacon strips or sausage is great. Burgers and crinkle cut fries are super and the Gyros are the best. When I bring food back to the office the aroma sends my co-workers across to Pittsfield Cafe.

While it's hidden - tucked inside an office building's lobby - Pittsfield offers a great, quick, and reasonably priced meal.  I've only come here for breakfast, and it's so good, I've been several times.  Only rarely are there lines, but even when there's a wait, the kitchen staff usually has pretty quick ticket times.  The coffee is great (not the lattes, but the drip coffee) and the Greek toast, eggs, and hashbrowns are delicious!

We walked past the entrance to this place a couple of times.  It's hidden inside what looked like an old office building from the outside.   There is seating outside the cafe, in the lobby.  It was pretty packed when we arrived for brunch but we didn't have to wait long to be seated (party of 7).  Nothing extraordinary but I did like the warm mom 'n pop feeling of the place.   Food was good and at great prices.
Called in for breakfast having seen recommendation in guide book. Not easy to find as inside office lobby. Good choice, good service, recommend. Take credit cards now

We headed out for brunch and couldn't face the queue at some nearby place that also had good yelp reviews, but had tourists and locals spewing out the door.  Come here for your weekend brunch, there  was no queue, no gaggles of tourists, but there really should be because this place was perfect...   The food was excellent and pretty damn cheap, the service was impeccable.   I couldn't decide which veggie benedict I wanted, so my server suggested one of each.   They split the bill without asking (are they mind readers?), kept coffee and water topped up.

Like a little hidden oasis, this place is Chicago's answer to the Garden of Eden (although they frowned on it when I walked in wearing only a fig leaf). Cool location in the Pittsfield Building.  It's really nice to sit in the atrium area and admire the beautiful architecture. Generous portions.  All the food was tasty.  Plenty of coffee.  Great service. You need to get a key to use the restroom.

I loved this location. It's in an old building with a grand lobby and tucked away in the back it's an old school diner. I chose to sit in the lobby to enjoy the view and be by myself. I've read some reviews that say its cash only but that's not the case (anymore I guess). Te service was outstanding. My server even buttered my toast!  I went with the 3 egg omelette hold the mushrooms add feta. I was extremely full and satisfied when I left. I didn't need to eat lunch that day!  Great prices for what you get. My bill was about $12 and my meal included orange juice, toast and hash browns. No sourdough was a bummer but the rye was good.
Old school! I had good service and food was good. Old Chicago building the Pittsfield from 1930's.

We were in the loop working our tails off to find a restaurant that wasn't a chain and wasn't pretentious, but still open on the weekend. We had to work pretty hard to get to Pittsfield, but it was just what we were hoping for: unpretentious, homey food in an unpretentious atmosphere for an unpretentious price. We will definitely be back.

Awful....I wanted to have breakfast downtown and was sadly disappointed with this place. The food had no seasoning. I ordered a chopped steak with eggs toast and hashbrowns. The toast was the best part

Looking for an out of the way breakfast place on a weekday in chicago and yelp led me to this classic diner.  It is hidden in a classic old building and we ordered a variety of classic diner fare (pancakes, egg, etc).  The food was cooked to order and good quality and the old building bumped this from 3 to 3.5 stars. Also, quite affordable for downtown chicago.

It is possible to get heart healthy food here.  I came to the Pittsfield building for a hair appointment and picked up my lunch to go.  I had a scrambled egg white, and  fresh fruit medley.  It was very good, and not overly expensive. For carry out, you order at the food case, pay, and then pick up your packaged food.

They should charge "Blast from the Past" admission fee here.   I love the simple "cafeteria-esque" white bowls/plates that are diner legit. Bus boy was on my water glass like a clockwork Niagara Falls. If you use the restroom downstairs - pack your rosary - this lav is haunted! The ladies room has old-school dark-brown wooden doors affixed to marble slabs with light-brown stenciled "for security of your purse hang it on the hook" with missing hooks on the back of the door. The foggy mirrors above porcelain sinks with manual water spigots reflect the charm of a different era. I heard faint moans...or was that just the plumbing? I don't know but I'm calling it:  A side of ghost with your coffee & toast! Now back to our diner: I had a quick lunch but not to be forgotten: The chicken rice soup was a tad too lemony initially, but now I remember it so fondly! Add a grilled cheese and you're almost home.  Give me more, I say...this time with a juicy bloody mary, as I've heard all good things about them. I love a little diner with a liquor license. My waitress (I usually say "server" but I want to say "waitress" here & it's a a total compliment) was swift and pleasant and don't fault me if I want to remember her wearing a white apron around her waist - the one with the bow in the back - tied over one of those off-mustard-yellow one piece outfits.   You can sit inside or outside...the "outside" being in the belly of the "Pittsfield Building" which is packed with stone and gilded charisma. The chandelier is quietly glorious. This outside dining was especially divine as I was there 'round Christmastime and the giant tree added some "all that."   I think there was something about a $10 minimum on a credit card, so mind your cash, or just order more! Yep, the best news is that you CAN eat here for under ten bucks and there is no "Blast from the Past" admission fee. Seriously tip your waitress! WOO!

Pittsfield almost always gets the job done and they get that job done cheaply.  A hot lunch for two under $15?  Tell me more. Pittsfield is that hidden gem that makes a gloomy Friday at work a little brighter... until it's darker because my eyes closed because I'm taking a nap at my desk now.  Oops.  I generally go for the patty melt and it's a pretty good rendition.  Nicely toasted marble rye on that baby.  Coworkers swear by the soups and BLTs.  Corned beef hash is their breakfast star.  I'll eat hash just about anywhere, but this one is nice and salty.  Yelp knows I'm like a baby deer to a salt lick. We usually order for pickup and it's ready by the time we've gotten our coats on and get out the door, but eating in is also nice in their funny pretend patio that's fenced in but inside the Pittsfield office building.   They used to be cash only but now they take cards.  Yay.

If you LOVE BREAKFAST this is the spot for although I almost always have lunch here I still order the breakfast. Favorites are French toast and hash browns, or the 2 - 2 - 2 (2 pancakes, 2 eggs, and 2 sausage).  Everyone I bring here loves it also, and I have had several meetings with 8 - 10 people and we have always been able to talk and hear each other. The servers one of the best things about the joint, friendly and fast.  Never have an empty drink or an empty stomach.

Cheap diner breakfast, and while I recall eating the sausage gravy and biscuits, nothing about the meal stuck as exemplary. That is, until the bloody mary came a-knockin'. A full pint of tomato mix, booze and spice is one thing; the veritable breadless sandwich suspended by a damn strong toothpick across the brim of the glass took it well-beyond the next level. It beat the game. It stomped Bowser. It saved the Princess. Salami, provolone cheese, a cherry tomato, a carrot, an olive, a lemon and a honkin' stalk of celery. Nine bucks and worth every penny, even if the wodka is rotgut (it ain't) and the mix is canned (it probably is). No gourmet, no gastrotech, no bullshit. But for fair fare and a baller bloody, Pittsfield is ittsfield!* *I will never apologize for that horrific last line. Ever.

Great food. Kind service. Fast kitchen. What else can you ask for? I spent more than I wanted, but that's my fault. I made my own omelette and got chicken, onion and avocado (with egg whites). Almost everything was an extra charge. But it was huge, hot and delicious. For $16 including tip I got breakfast and lunch in one meal, unlimited coffee and talked with a wonderful server.

Pittsfield Cafe has the best tasting corned hash. Has the corned beef hash been a little less on the too soggy part, I would have given this place a 5-star. Still, I couldn't help myself shoving a forkful of it in my mouth.  It is located inside the Pittsfield building with an amazing interior. .

This really is as good as it gets when it comes to diners.  Hidden away in a building, so not too crowded, attentive service, good coffee, and delicious diner food.  I was here during a conference and it was so nice to duck into some place no one could find me and have a friendly wait staff greet me with a hot cup of coffee!  And definitely do get the Avocado Eggs Benedict.  Yum!  I never had to ask for anything - not for a refill, not for the bill, not for change.  That's magic.
This place is great, the food fantastic, the history of the building is fun, and the prices are great.

I remember the days of going to this diner as a fave lunch spot with my coworkers.  I would always order the spinach feta omlette with toast and fries or hash brown.  It's the best place to go when you are craving a hometown breakfast.  It is cash only and I am glad to see that after 5 years of not going here that it is still around.  Will definitely make a stop here when I visit Chicago again.

The perfect diner that city residents crave- great prices, classic on-point diner service, matzoh ball soup- the whole package! Service is better if you sit inside (as opposed to "outside", which is still inside the building's atrium). A true gem!

I work across the street and love this place. I pretty much get an egg white Denver omelet. But I have eaten salads and some other things and I really enjoy this place. I can call in my order, run to the bathroom and run across the street in five minutes and my food is done. I've gone once or twice for lunch and ate inside the building, service is fast and friendly. It's a typical greek dinner type place with food but its convenient in the loop. Coffee is also pretty good. I enjoyed the soup the one time I got it. Burger wasn't anything special but still decent.  If in the area and looking for some good breakfast, give it a try!

what a beautiful building that the pittsfield cafe is nestled in. my husband and i had a quick brunch here while visiting chicago. we so happen to walk by, saw a sign, and decided to give it a try. my husband ordered a bacon wrapped hot dog while i ordered a breakfast sandwich on a croissant. the hot dog was simple enough with a side of crinkle cut fries. it hit the spot for my husband. the breakfast sandwich was also well done. i was in awe of the ornate trim and lighting of the lobby where we dined. it truly had character.
Great little diner. Food was cheap and good, extremely friendly and prompt service. Great spot for out-of-towners looking for a diner breakfast or lunch.

Is exactly what it wants to be, and exactly what I needed to nurse my saturday morning hangover! Good food, no wait, fast & friendly service, very reasonably priced, and a good bloody Mary! Thanks to my fellow helpers for steering me here!
Great out of the way place no tourists and no wait time on the weekend. Food was excellent

I've never been a fan of diners, but Pittsfield has shown me that you can't judge a book by its cover. I really like this place. I've had several different things here including their blue cheese burger, a chicken philly, and a garlic chicken wrap. All were delicious. They have a wide menu so I'm gonna try some other things too sense I've had such success with everything else. The staff there is always friendly, and the pricing is decent. I go here for lunch with plenty time to spare, which is pretty quick. Try it!

This is a pretty cool little diner tucked in the corner of an open lobby on the ground floor of a downtown skyscraper.  It's like a calm oasis surrounded by the hustle and bustle of city life. The diner features a nice selection of breakfast and sandwich lunch dishes.  Nothing super fancy, but still nice and tasty. I enjoyed the two eggs, two pancakes and two pieces of bacon special.  I thought it was priced perfectly at about $5.75, but was a bit disappointed in being charged $2.25 for a 12-ounce Dr. Pepper. I should have looked a little closer at the menu. If you want a quick time out to grab some food and calm your thoughts. This is a good place to go.

Perfect. Hidden. Quiet. Friendly. Cheap. Fresh. Tasty! What more can I say? This place rocks! We went here because of the great reviews and we were not disappointed. The staff are super-friendly and welcoming. The coffee is excellent and fresh. My breakfast was cooked to perfection. And the bill was tiny.

Wow, I can't believe I've worked in the Loop for almost 5 years and have never been here- what a tragedy! I was craving pancakes and this diner does serve breakfast all day I believe- or at least till after 1:00 PM when I went there. Delicious and my eggs were cooked perfectly which I don't always get when I order them over hard, fried, no runny yolk. Bacon was nice and crispy too! Also got an extra large fresh OJ which was SO good. Service is indeed fast and very sweet and friendly. Many repeat customers came in while I was there and were addressed by name. I love a place like that and they are getting harder to find. This is a gem and I hope it never goes away. Oh and they do take cards now but I heard someone say there is a $10 minimum.

Wonderful little breakfast place. Friendly faces and quick.  We tried a few other places around Michigan and the lines where all the way outside.  This is a great, classic breakfast, without the weight.

I was told about this place by a tourist guide at the visitor's center.  You have to look for it because it doesn't have a street sign, just a sandwich board on the street.  It is in a beautiful old building with "outdoor" seating in the lobby.  The coffee is served in large mugs, hot and tasty.  The 222 breakfast is only $5.75 and provides a basic breakfast. I had 2 eggs, 2 pancakes and 2 bacon slices. Delicious. It wasn't crowded, but it should have been. Other breakfasts in the area are not as good and cost twice as much.

Found this cafe on yelp during our first visit to Chicago.  So glad we did, ate here 3 times for breakfast during our stay.  Great coffee, good variety, reasonable prices.  Food was served fast and hot. They do accept credit cards. Surprisingly no wait. a hidden gem!

Pittsfield Cafe is  located at Washington / Wabash - The soup which they have everyday, all summer long it THE best soup I've ever had.  I eat lunch there everyday and always have a cup of chicken soup - The staff is all great, Pat, Delphina and Memo are my regular servers..yes, I'm a regular now...the gyros are amazing, the salads are all good...everything is good, fast and friendly.
Great food - and great value!  Chocolate chip pancakes; I felt like Homer Simpson eating them! GO HERE for breakfast! I command you.

Read all the reviews on Yelp and decided to come here for breakfast on a Saturday.  There was no wait for a table and we were able to order right away. The coffee is great!  I was actually kind of shocked by how good it was.  Hash browns were right on the money.   Cheap, fast and good.  They all add up to a great Saturday morning breakfast!!

Cute little diner tucked away in an office building. Avocado benedict? Yes please. Who needs canadian bacon when you can have avocado? Surprisingly good coffee (that goes for iced as well!), reasonable prices, and quick service.

Great out the the way place for excellent and fresh standard american diner fare.  Breakfast all day and a good variety of sandwiches and simple meals.  The Shakes and burgers, Gyros and pancakes are worth the trek.  Bring cash they don't take credit cards

I love this place! I work near the Pittsfield Building so we order from there all the time. Besides the convenience  their food is good American diner fare from breakfast to lunch. I love their salads, especially the Chicken Caesar and the Cobb. They have a great egg, sausage and cheese croissant and they have great coffee. You can eat there or take out. The staff is friendly and does their best to get you served quickly.  So, if you're in the Loop and want good basic diner food then stop here instead of a fast food place.

You have to look closely as you walk by the Pittsfield building but there will be a sign and a menu on the street. Once inside as you walk toward the cafe a friendly young face will come out of  no where and greet you. The young guy is one of the owner's. The service was fast and the food awesome! My wife had the veggie omelet, my son had the eggs, pancakes and bacon meal, my daughter had the BBQ sandwich and I had the Gyro omelet. All was cooked to perfection and for the breakfasts you get a huge amount of hashbrowns to go with it. The coffee was excellent! Why is it so hard to find good coffee? For you sports fan's we were there at 11:30 am on a Saturday and they have several big screen t.v's on with college football on every station As we were finishing up we asked where we could find a bookstore so the owner gets one of his buddies to look it up on his iphone and before long we were heading to the store. Now that's service! Being a business owner myself I loved the attention to detail given and the personable and family atmosphere of the place. We'll definitely be back.

Good. Greasy. Cheap. I don't know why there aren't more college kids here. It's cheap, and it's on the first floor of my dorms. I didn't expect great quality at these prices, and I didn't get it. But it was standard diner fare. Great service, good coffee, beautiful indoor courtyard seating.

5, yes 5 stars. Count 'em up.  I started my morning going to the dentist so by the time lunch came around I was starving and in the need of a little food TLC.  Enter, Pittsfield.  Thank you, Yelpers, for helping me make this lunch decision. I was excited to try this "hidden gem" in the city - and boy, is this little darlin' a GEM.  Let's start with the bad:  1. Nothing Let's move on to the good:  1. Good coffee (I know I'm not the only one who thinks good coffee is hard to come by) 2. Great staff - Grrrrrrreat (cue Tony the Tiger).  3. Fresh squeezed orange juice - out of this world excited about this! 4. The building... ...let's talk about the building.  This is located in an old timey building that houses businesses, a barber shop and such. I chose to sit in the lobby to enjoy my lunch and wow - what a cool atmosphere. Imagine sitting and enjoying a cup 'o joe in the middle of a vintage building smack dab in the middle of the city. Well, imagine no more my friends, Pittsfield is IT.  A few things to note:  -- If you're in a rush to eat, this is THE place for you. The food service takes 5 mins. at most. WOW! How many full service joints in the city can claim such fast service? Not many.  -- CASH ONLY! But, not to worry, Yelpers. There is a Chase bank on the corner with an ATM.  What I ordered/ate:  -- South of the Border omlette -- Rasin Toast -- Fruit cup -- Coffee -- OJ Honestly, good service gets me every time. So when I walked up to the entrance of this diner and an older man kindly greeted me and sat me down telling me, "Wherever you like!" in a happy tone, I fell in love.  I want you all to go and love it, but please save a spot for me. I can't imagine my life without Pittsfield.

Best hidden find in Chicago.  Located inside a big hotel I think.  I'll post a picture or two later.  A perfect american diner you'd never find unless you were looking for it.  Cash only so be prepared.  Prices very reasonable and service superb.  Food was very good, coffee filled often, and fresh squeezed OJ excellent.  Well worth our 7 block walk from our hotel.  Won't miss this one again.

Pittsfield is a Loop-area blast from the past with a makeover, as far as your tucked away little greasy spoon diners are concerned. If you are hankering for something like a big mess of eggs, hash browns and toast--perhaps cooked the way old school gangsters were accustomed to--this is your spot. I'm a big fan of their avocado skillet, which comes with 3 eggs (mine over easy), a chunk of hash browns under that, a generous amount of avocado sliced throughout and topped with melted cheese.  Your heart will swear that you've declared war against it.  Easily distracted by nearby popular destinations such as Millennium Park and the Chicago Cultural Center, it's very easy to walk right by this gem without even knowing it. It sits smack dab in the middle of a historic building.

This place is seriously a hidden gem. Their menu is HUGE and I haven't had anything I didn't like. I especially love going their for breakfast and fresh OJ! The service is great and the friendly owners are always there to great you. Not to mention that the prices are extremely reasonable. Even though I don't live in the loop anymore, I will absolutely be making the trip downtown to eat at Pittsfield Cafe.

I was staying at Hotel Burham, which is a block or so away and I needed a quick bite to eat before my flight out.  The front desk recommended this place since it was also close to Millennium Park, which I also wanted to see before I headed out.  Pittsfield Cafe is inside the Pittsfield building so you won't be able to see it from the streets.  We went there on a Saturday around 7am and it was pretty quiet.   The price is really good and the service is fantastically fast!  The breakfast food was simple and delicious...nothing fancy but not greasy so definitely a plus for me.    If I'm in the area again, I would come back.  The service, food, price and diner feel were all great.   If you didn't read the other reviews, BRING CASH!  It is redundant to mention but I think it's an important thing to know and continue :P

I love this place simply because it's one of the only true diners around. I used to go to diners regularly when I lived in NYC and haven't found too many in Chicago.  True to diner form, the service here is beyond speedy. Your food seems to arrive before you've even finished ordering it. That said, this place has very standard diner fare, which means you should probably stick with certain types of food that diners do best. I usually go for a grilled cheese or a tuna melt--something along those lines. For whatever reason, I find that the tap water here is on the disgusting side, so I almost always order a Coke. Since it's tucked away in the Pittsfield building, it seems like a lot of people don't know about this place (judging by how many of my coworkers were unaware of it). It never gets overly crowded, although I do try to get there around noon so that I can sit in the section that's outside the restaurant itself (you're less likely to leave smelling of diner food by sitting there). All in all, I think this is a nice hidden gem if you're looking for a diner experience.
Good food.  Decent prices.  Fast and friendly service.  Cool old diner feel.  Cash only.

Why anyone wouldn't give this place 5 stars is beyond me.  It's a small diner feel with a great menu.  Plus while you're inside eating you can  forget you live in the city.  Service is continually good and the owners are extremely nice.
Great breakfast place.  In the lobby of the impressive Pittsfield Bldg.  Get the french toast!  Thick and tasty.

As noted by others, this is clearly posted "CASH ONLY" one must wonder how a business can survive in todays economy with a CASH ONLY policy. They offer many specials for that breakfast stop before work, for about $6 you can get 2 eggs, 2 strips of bacon, 2 slices of buttered toast w/jelly and 3/4 plate full of hashbrowns. Service is very fast and they stayed on top of refills. First time to visit this location and so far I like it. The hostess needs to liven up her personality a bit, otherwise, all was good. They offer inside the lobby seating or seating inside the cafe, they have a full counter with stools to sit at an dine. Take-away is available at a side counter. Looking forward to trying for lunch sometime soon.

Let's get this out of the way first... BRING CASH! I know the cash register says cash only, but if you opt for a seat outside the restaurant, in the lobby, then you might not see that (especially if you are as oblivious as I am). With that minor annoyance out of the way, this place is a perfect little breakfast spot in a neat location. The menu is huge and filled with everything from pancakes and waffles to build-your-own omlettes. The prices are relatively reasonable given its location between Michigan and State in the loop (ok, just barely outside the loop), and the service was attentive and friendly. We came here for breakfast on New Year's Eve, which was a Friday, and seating was readily available. I'm guessing seats may be a little harder to come by on a normal weekday or Saturday, but there appears to be plenty of seating both inside and outside (outside meaning, outside of the restaurant space, but still within the lobby of the building in which the restaurant is located). I would definitely come back here again and again, as it beats the pants off the nearest breakfast competition, which is the Atwood Cafe (see my review of that one).

I can not give a CASH ONLY place more than a 4 star  as it is just not convenient.  I can't help to think what kind of taxes they are not paying.  This is a local place that has good food.  They need to update their menu with the correct "cafe" drinks as I tried to order several and they didn't even have them, yet they were on the menu.  This is not the place to deviate from the menu with custom requests as they will unlikely be able to accommodate.  The bathroom is out in the main building and down the stairs which is rather inconvenient.  On the upswing the food was good, I have a skillet and my husband had a basic bacon and eggs.  Nothing to get all excited about, but a fair start to your morning.

Down the slippery slope we continue. Been eating food from this place on and off for 20 years but now only about 1x every 3 weeks as they deliver. Used to be every day. I have pretty low standards for this place but today was a new low.  Had food delivered to the office as we normally do. [Have refused to eat inside for 4 years, which is another story]. Order was screwed up, i.e. salad no dressing, no roll.  Hot  dog on a cold stale bun.  Called to get replacements.  They sent over a bun 15 minutes later.  No hot dog.  Just a plain bun! How cheap can you go?  Of course the hot dog became a cold dog in the process. Pea soup, Got to be the strangest in the city.  Go to Bacci around the corner for decent soup and a decent lunch in my opinion.

Yuck. I ordered Spinach Pie and Split Pea soup. I've never had either, so it's hard to say if it's just the actual dish that was bad or if it was the way they made it. Split Pea soup was simply gross and had a strange consistency. Plus, the croutons tasted old and weird. Gross. After a few spoonfulls it went in the garbage.The spinach pie wasn't too bad, but had kind of a strange flavor to it. It would be okay if I didn't start feeling super sick to my stomach 10 minutes after eating it. "Yeah, so now I feel sick. Great. I also ordered an Apple Pie which is now sitting in my fridge, so we'll see how that tastes. I'll update you guys once I know.  Another downside is that the place is cash only and it is only open till 5pm. It's in my building though which makes it convenient. Well anyhow, I am willing to try something that I actually know how it tastes like next time and I will update my review once I do. Until then.

Been here twice.  Totes adorbs.  Silver dollar pancakes?  the description on the menu: "little cakes from heaven".  Less that, than chewy little discs of carbs, but a filling cheap lunch.  The BLT was solid the last time I came. Why I eschewed the grilled cheese is beyond me.

The only thing that makes me as happy as sitting with a glass of wine and an egg salad sandwich in the interior courtyard of the Pittsfield Building looking up at all the 1920s Gothic Revivial architecture is chugging along on the ferry from Sorrento to Capri, and the Pittsfield experience is a lot cheaper.  Something about being in an ornate indoor courtyard in a funky, downmarket Loop building soothes the soul.  Although not everyone's apparently--my brilliant hair stylist Danny Valles reported peering down into the courtyard from his compact little salon on an upper floor and witnessing a fight break out among a bunch of construction workers who had come to the cafe for lunch.  He said that when the cops arrived no one claimed to know who started the fight and they all protected each other.  I only hope this was witnessed by some genteel old lady customer in white gloves.
It's a diner. in the loop. Finish your grilled cheese and go back to work.

People seem to have had good experiences with the service, but I definitely didn't. First they got my order wrong... I ordered two pancakes and two eggs, they gave me two pancakes and two pieces of bacon. Not a huge deal, it happens. But when I told them they'd gotten in wrong, the woman who took my order repeatedly insisted that I was the one who was wrong. I'm 100% sure I did not order bacon, stop trying to insist that I did. Then she started whispering with the cook and giving me dirty looks, which made me afraid they were spitting on my food. Secondly, when I went to pay they charged me $1.20 more than the breakfast special which was two pancakes, two eggs, and two pieces of bacon. When I asked why I wasn't getting the breakfast special price they said that since I hadn't gotten the bacon they had to ring up the items a la carte. This  makes zero sense. I should have just gotten the special and thrown away the bacon, but I was trying to save them money. The food was okay, but I won't be going there again.

Things I love about Chicago, Greek families that have slung our hash for the past 120 years. Getting off the el in the dead of winter at sunrise,  or earlier. Breakfast,  there is no city with better breakfast,  well not consistently anyway. I can bring all these loves together in one fell swoop at the Pittsfield diner,  get off the Orange line,  walk less than a block,  enter this stalwart of Chicago history.  Stroll straight through the grandiose lobby that is reminiscent of a European courtyard or square.   Grab a hot cup of coffee,  breakfast,  and a clean bathroom downstairs.  I can do this all for under $7.  Question is,  how long can they?   Fast,  good eats in a beautiful historic building,  maybe I will see you there,  better not have a jimmy Johns with ya!

Let me explain my diner fetish. Never mind.  I don't want to see your GenY smirk, or listen to your haughty disregard for tradition, historical significance or a good grilled cheese sandwich. To hell with you.  You'll never appreciate the ancient Greek owner who welcomes all, or the decor of the Pittsfield (bringing to mind Rudolph Valentino's mausoleum), or the fact that this building contains a store that makes police badges.  POLICE BADGES!  Just keep going to Jimmy John's, you Philistines.

They only accept cash and their prices have only gone up.  For being a breakfast and lunch place, you'd think they would have a wider variety of lunch specials (like soup + sandwich?!), but they don't. Their food is well prepared and quick to your table, even during the rush times.  Their split pea soup on Tuesdays is their best one, and I would often pick up a Jimmy Johns sandwich to have with it.  Aside from that it's diner food, so order accordingly.

1 star for the friendly service. 1 star for the prices. Otherwise, um, no. I was in the mood for a relaxing morning of reading at a diner, and decided on the Pitsfield because of it's location, prices, and, well, its seems like it could be cute. I got a burger. I do not expect a Kuma's burger at any diner. I also do not expect a stale bun, wilted lettuce, and cold fries. I also ordered an iced coffee (I realize that might be a bit much for a diner) and did not even try to make it past 3 sips. I'd go to any other divey diner before this one.

I will go back to try the breakfast menu.  I went there for lunch, I had a taste for a good tuna melt.  It was okay.  The service is great!!!  Relaxing, casual and comfortable place to eat and chat.   Friendly and attentive serivce.  Food does come out very quickly.  It's your basic diner food in the middle of downtown.   Serving of food is huge. CASH ONLY is the downside...who carries cashon them these days?

A great place for a casual lunch.  An old fashioned deli lunch counter in a beautiful building.  Very good food.The Matzah ball soup is the best I've found in Chicago's downtown.  Relaxed.  Unpretentious.  Good service.

It is what it is. Greasy diner food. However, when I have a hankerin' for just that, it fits the bill. Good reuben & gyros.  Downsides: Cash only. I have to lay down afterwards. Bizarre hours. Upsides: Staff is fantastic & super friendly. Perfect hangover food. Quick to get in and out. Love the Pittsfield Building.
I love eating breakfast here. The service is quick and the prices are modest :-). Lunch is great as well. They make a mean mac & cheese.

- quick - perfect diner food - limited hours - beautiful surroundings in the lobby This place reminds me of what might've been the 1920s urban diner. I have been coming here ever since I moved to Chicago in '02 and not much has changed, including the servers. If you sit in the lobby area you will be entertained by the incredible beauty that is the Pittsfield Building. Everywhere you look has been crafted with love. But we need to talk about the food. It's great diner food. They keep early hours, so if you're a 6a breakfast person this is the place for you. I usually get breakfast here. And strangely when then are their busiest is when they shine, like a well-oiled machine. Once I ordered breakfast and by the time I reached in my bag for some work it was sizzling away in front of me. There's not a bad place to sit. If you're at the counter you can watch the symphony in action.

It's a hidden gem.  Located inside the unassuming Pittsfield building a great little diner that is fast and cheap and magically delicious.  The wait staff is friendly, a bit older, but I prefer that to some kid that would rather be anyplace besides work.  I had the French toast (thick sliced, not soggy or eggy but perfectly griddled.  Also, there wasn't any powdered sugar- my personal preference.) & bacon (only two slices, but super crispy- not the least bit greasy).  My wife had two eggs over medium (perfectly cooked- runny yolks and firm whites) with toast & hashnrowns. The hasbrowns seemed to be under cooked but she liked them and I didn't try them, so I won't comment on them further.  We each had coffe (numerous refills w/o waiting or asking) and water.  All this for less than 20 bucks, including tip.  Honest breakfast fare for an honest price, what more can you ask for in the city?

what a little gem! unless i worked in the building, i would've had no idea this place existed. my boyfriend lives in the loop; as a result, we're always struggling to find great restaurants that are open on the weekends. after a little yelping - enter, pittsfield cafe. i was able to appreciate the "indoor patio" outside the restaurant, but my partner-in-crime thought it was a little weird, so we ate inside. we were quickly greeted with waters and menus; our waitress couldn't have been sweeter. most of the people inside seemed to be regulars, since the staff was on a first name basis with several of them. our mission was breakfast, but their menu was surprisingly extensive. it's a diner with a little bit of greek in it. after a small debate, we settled on: jumping bean omelet (jalapenos, onions, tomato & cheese) two eggs over easy with corn beef hash the portions were huge! my omelet had to have at least three eggs in it. almost everything on the breakfast menu comes with potatoes and your choice of toast & jelly. add a coffee on the bill and we got out of there for only $18. everything else that came out of the kitchen (sandwiches included) looked delicious. i'm pretty sure their gyros will kick some major ass. an important note - pittsfield is cash only. they also have breakfast specials that are good from 6am - 11am. we'll definitely be back!

Tried Pitsfield for the first time today! I love the location, kind of a drab old building and when you turn the corner, Pitsfield Cafe!  First things first, the people were extremely nice. I was seated right away at the counter, since I was dining alone. It was me and a handful of old guys. The kind you wish you could listen to tell you a story about the old days... I had a tuna melt deluxe. Came with fries, cole slaw and a cold pickle. It was very good! I have heard so much about the breakfast, so I can't wait to go back!!!  Thank you Pitsfield Cafe!
No windows that face the outside world, they all face an interior court in the building. Like eating in a subway. Otherwise seemed fine.

Next time you are craving diner food in the Loop head inside the Pittsfield building at Wabash and Washington. This cozy little diner is perfect for breakfast or lunch, just beware they sometimes close early. I enjoy reading a paper and eating their crinkle cut fries at the counter. I also love their Gryos plate which is enormous. Prices are a bit steep for a diner so I'll knock off a star for that. Otherwise all-around great atmosphere, friendly service, and outstanding food. Yay!

My GF and I stumbled upon/into this place after walking around for over an hour on St. Pat's day looking for a place that wasn't packed to the rafters with drunks and still served breakfast around noon time. Of course, if the river dyeing had been anywhere NEAR on time (it was her first time, and boy, was it crap this year!), we wouldn't have had that problem. I digress. Service = quite friendly, if a little inattentive. Food = tasty, served hot, though a little overpriced, IMO. (Her pancakes, eggs & OJ and my mushroom burger + 2 coffees ran about $26.00). If I worked in the area, I'd probably stop by every other week or so.

Walking through the Pittsfield Building, up to this place makes you feel like you're in the "Untouchables" you'll certainly impress your friends when you take them into the lobby for lunch. But they do back it up with genial customer service, and standard diner fare done right (except the fries could be done a little more right, I guess) but Eliot Ness would have felt at home- I guess.  Be careful it's cash only.

Good prices, good food.  The same people have worked there for years -  very nice folks.  Gyro omelette is a real treat.  Unfortunately I cannot give Pittsfield five stars for they have committed the most egregious of all restaurant errors - -not having Heinz catchup in glass bottles.  They have a far inferior product.  Pity.

After my doctor's appointment, I was feening the coffee.  I knew I had already passed LaVazza, Starbucks, and Dunkin Donuts and to do my due diligence and support the local cafe.  It seemed really cozy and suprising to find this diner in the city.  I would have never thought one would exist.  I like the idea of amongst the skyskrapers and business people that there's this place that you can find that might remind you of some small town you dropped in on.  I would have liked to sit and stay, but I did have to go back to work.  I asked the hostess about any coffee I could take to go and she led me to the coffee area, where I got my own cup.  It wasn't great, but I just really like the ambiance and the lady was really making me feel like I was in another era.  My coffee and banana were $2.75 or something like that.  So, they also offer fruit, desserts, and bags of potato chips for on the go.  I may have to wake up a bit earlier to get breakfast before I go in for my appointment the next time.

Anytime we're having a bad day or feeling hungover, my coworkers and I head to the Pitt.  Something about the ambiance of this place just makes you feel warm and fuzzy inside.   I've had many things on the menu, but one of my favorites is the Grecian Salad.  Weird for a diner, I know, but it's always fresh and delicious.  My coworkers love the spicy fries, BLT, gyro, and mac and cheese (available Fridays).   I certainly wouldn't call this place overpriced- in fact, I think it's one of the more affordable places for a sit down meal in the loop, but be sure you bring cash. I've also never had to wait for a table here, even during the peak of lunch hour.  Service is always friendly and usually pretty quick. And some good news, they're now open for dinner too!

When I used to work at Marshall Fields (yes, Fields, not Macy's, this was like 10 years ago people when I worked there) I would go here at least 3-5 times a week.  Seriously. What brought me to Pittsfield Café?  It's an awesome diner.  They have a counter for singles and tables for groups.  They will sit singles at the tables, but I always ate at the counter because they have limited space during rush hour. Back to what makes Pittsfield (that's what we call it) awesome: -Diner seating! -No nonsense staff that is actually friendly and remember the repeat customers.   -Really good BLT, seriously the best in Chicago.  ORDER IT!  Other good items are the breakfast specials and a killer turkey salad on croissant.  CROSSANT!  -FYI: They have greek toast, if you don't know what that is, it is a thicker slice of white bread with SEASAME SEEDS on the crust of the bread.  IT'S THE TOAST JESUS EATS WHEN HE IS IN CHICAGO!   -Quick friendly service and turnaround (important for lunches in the loop) So Pittsfield is so great I took my parents here when they visited from central Iowa.  I made them jump on the "el" with me and travel a good 20 minutes from east pilsen (where I lived 10 years ago way before University Village was built) to eat breakfast.  You know what happened?  My dad was jealous of my Greek toast and told me I should have advised him to get some too! HA! They offer pick-up service.  You can call in your order and pick it up!  I never did this because it was so close, but now that I work in the south loop I do fantasize about the turkey croissant, but usually tell myself I will get up early some day and have breakfast before work and then walk to work (15 minute walk).   I'm not a morning person so that never happens! Lastly I just want to say this café was so good I wasn't the only repeat customer from Marshall Fields.  I worked in the cosmetics department and most of us went on breakfast breaks and lunch here together.  You would go and run into at least another table that was from our department.  I wouldn't be surprised if there were other tables from the store because it's really a jem.

Suddenly a place that used to be the neighborhood favorite is charging prices like they're a five star restaurant!   This was a place that all the nearby offices  used to congregate  for a quick breakfast or lunch.  It was familiar and friendly and REASONABLY PRICED!  Now you will be disappointed with the PRICES and the food!  The prices have gone UP and the quality of the food has gone DOWN!  The owners are really nice and I realize that prices are going up for them too but a burger and pop really shouldn't cost $10.00 for lunch + TIP!  A fountain pop $2.25?  This has to cost them  all of 5 CENTS!  With the constant construction workers marching through and half the atrium tables gone you'd think they would do something to encourage people instead of sending more people away.  It's really sad!

Firstly, for people out of town typing in "breakfast, chicago" into the search bar, you have to find the Pittsfield building and go right inside; you can't see this place from the outside. But otherwise, another great find from Yelp.  We got a corn-beef hash and french toast, both being the great diner breakfast you would expect.  A few cups of joe and you're ready to hit the town; after a breakfast like this lunch is very much optional. Due to it's recessed location it's not touristy or overpriced; we left a $20 and that was with a generous tip.

A coworker of mine and I walked into the Pittsfield Cafe one day for lunch knowing nothing about it. When you first walk into the historic Pittsfield Building, you instantly notice the five-story atrium that the cafe is situated in. It's a bit strange, actually, because you can be seated "outside" the actual restaurant, but it's still inside this atrium. It's kind of cool, I suppose, but that's not the point. Inside is actually a bit more like a diner than a cafe, but it wasn't bad at all. We decided to just order wraps, and they were very good. The price was a little steep for what we got though. The service was excellent, and the food came out super fast. An old lady in our vicinity was chatting it up with us, but she was cool and we were down. Overall, it was a pretty good experience. I have no major complaints. That might also be due to the fact that it's one of the few good places close to my work. Oh, also, my coworker tried to pay with a debit card, but it's cash only (which of course meant I had to cover her ass).

I didn't grow up in the US, so I'm relatively new to diners as a concept. This one certainly won my affection, notwithstanding the mildly grumpy waitress and another attendant's propensity to mop the floor with smelly disinfectant while we were eating. (this has happened to me twice.) The breakfast is solid and quality, and the spinach pie really does come with half a canned peach on the side, I'm not sure why. The chocolate shake is incredible (though probably 500 calories). Best shake I've had in years.  i wish they had longer weekend hours!

The two-star is really for the dish I got, they tricked me with the Today's special of Deep Fried Smelts.  Smelts are little fish.  Kinda like anchovies on steroids, but without the offensive odor or roid rage.  That being said, the batter was forgettable and seemed haphazardly fried.  You could say it was comparable to the Mickey D's Filet-o-fish, which i love, in that they both have a common flavor of tartar sauce and the comparison ends there.   The service was okay and it looks like you get a nice bread bun (which they touch with their bare hands) with any order. Now the Boston Clam Chowder was good, although there was an impossibly large potato wedge in mine.  The breakfast food does look good, I admit, so if I go back and get some, I'm sure my stars will rise...

Sometimes, you're just in the mood for diner food and Pittsfield rarely disappoints. Some of their sandwiches tend to be on the greasy side, but there are enough choices on the menu that you shouldn't have a problem picking something tasty (or a less artery-clogging option if desired). As Richard wrote already, their cream of chicken with rice soup is delicious and very inexpensive! It's my favorite - look for it on Thursdays.  One of these days, I'll wake up early so I can go to Pitts for breakfast before work...

I love "The Pit". A group of us (4-5) used to have breakfast there at least 3 time a week.    Breakfast options are pretty standard, and I haven't been disappointed by anything I've had. It's also one of the only places I've run into downtown that you can sub grits for hash browns.  These days we seem to just order lunch for pickup.   Options at the pit consist of your basic diner eats with some Greek highlights here and there.  If available, I recommend the spinach pie and the cream of chicken & rice soup.  Tuesday (if memory serves me correctly), is split pea soup day, yum! They're super fast, always nice and make a mean Tuna Club.

Hungover at work? Need some grease? Call Pittsfields!  They deliver...although we normally pick it up.  Once you see their delivery  guy, you'll start seeing him all over the loop.  That man gets a ton of exercise.  It's basic diner food.  But their menu is pretty big. It has some healthy surprises scattered about.  As always, the people are pretty friendly.  I don't think I've ever had a crabby encounter.

This place has been around for ages. Open for breakfast and lunch only Monday-Saturday. Decent food, nothing fancy or really different. Good soup and sandwich lunch specials. A little something for everyone.Decent service and selection. Good place to drop in when you are in the Loop.I can't believe that no one else has reviewed "The Pitts" before! The Pittsfield Building is home to many doctors and dentists, so if you have an appointment here,try it for breakfast or lunch! Cash only-so bring your money!

ahh. the pits. it's so good.  it's in the first floor of the pitsfield building downtown...across from the cultural center. a big menu of diner food.  i need to go back, but everything i have had there is great!! breakfast and lunch only.
